name: Nicobar Pigeon
description: One of the most beautifully colored pigeons, it is relatively large with a base color of ashy gray, its back and wings shimmering in metallic shades of green, blue, and rust. Elongated neck feathers cascade into a mantle-like structure. Its short tail is white, legs gray, and toes red. The female has a white iris, while the male and young have brown irises.
spread_note: Southeast Asia and Pacific islands up to Papua New Guinea
image_alt: Nicobar pigeon, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
attractions: The closest living relative of the flightless dodo, though it hardly resembles it. By day, it flies in small flocks, foraging mostly on the ground. It is monogamous, with pairs typically permanent. It nests on smaller, quieter islands, forming colonies of up to a thousand during this time. Pigeons belong to the order of soft-billed birds, with an unusually soft upper beak, only the tip being truly hard. Herbivorous, their main diet consists of seeds and fruits. Though surprising for Czech species, many tropical pigeons boast vibrant colors rivaling parrots, making them prized ornamental birds for specialized breeders. All soft-billed birds—pigeons, their slimmer relatives the doves, and the robust ground-dwelling crowned pigeons—share unique traits: they lack a preen gland at the tail base, grooming with fine particles from down feathers, and produce 'pigeon milk,' a curd-like substance in their crop to feed their helpless young. Unlike most birds, they drink by immersing their beaks and sucking, rather than scooping and tilting their heads.
breeding: We have kept them at the zoo since 1969, but the first successful breeding occurred in 2000.
